December, Tasseng Yang at Khan Kho received Colonel Billy and Thai Colonel Khouphan. Colonel Billy's mission was to locate Vang Pao and assess the potential and desire of Hmongs to fight NVA and Pathet Lao. Vang Pao is located and contacted by Colonel Billy. US provided military support at Padong for Vang Pao [55].
Souvanna Phouma exiled himself to Cambodia [55].
Quinim Pholsena, a minister of Souvanna Phouma, bargained with Soviets to arm and supply those fighting General Phoumi under the condition that Kong Le and Pathet Lao form an alliance [55].
General Phoumi launched countercoup against Kong Le. Kong Le retreated to PDJ [55].
NVA successfully overtook General Phoumi's troops on Route 7 near Ban Ban [55].
Neutralists and communists began fight against General Phoumi at PDJ [55].
May, Geneva Conferences on Laos open under assumption of cease-fire [55].
In the late 1960's, the Pathet Lao Alphabet writing system was created for Hmong people [49].
In the late 1960's, the Whitelock Thai-based Alphabet writing system for the Hmong language was created [49].
Krushchev declared Soviet support for wars of national liberation in the face of incoming President Kennedy [55].
Kong Le, Pathet Lao and NVA stopped General Phoumi's attempt to retake PDJ. PDJ battles against Hmong and Royal Lao by the NVA , Kong Le and Pathet Lao broke out [55].
Bay of Pigs Invasion failed. Kennedy ordered covert White Star advisors in Laos to operate overtly in a counter-Khrushchev move. This action violated the Geneva Accords openly [55].
Summit in Vienna between Kennedy and Khrushchev [55].
North Vietnam denied the presence of NVA troops in Laos and did not withdrew any forces, while Americans withdrew 666 military men. By the end of August, there were 10,000 NVA in Laos [55].
US realized the threat of NVA presence in Laos and resorted to the Third Option--which is counterinsurgency and guerrilla warfare. Vang Pao moved his headquarter from Pha Khao to Long Chieng [55].
US pulled out White Star advisors to show good faith in Geneva Conference [55].

July, Geneva Accords reaffirmed Laos as a neutral state and prohibited foreign bases or troops. Kennedy negotiators in Geneva stated a Laos based on coalition government would emerge. General Phoumi would have to step down and Chao Souvanna Phouma would step into the leadership position of this new Laos. Forrestal and Sullivan, two of the negotiators, arrived in Laos to attempt to unite Vang Pao and Kong Le, which turns out unsuccessful. They observed the Vang Pao troop as being ill-equipped to fight their enemy [55].
August, NVA attacked Ban Ban area and as 6,000 Lao, Kmhmu and Hmong flee, they are caught, slaughtered and raped [55].
October, Cuban Missile Crisis [55].
Deadline for withdrawal of all foreign troops from Laos [55].
Shong Lue Yang fled from Tham Ha to Fi Kha when communist troops attempt to arrest him. He later sent a delegation to get protection from Vang Pao [49].
April, Pathet Lao attacked Kong Le and forced Kong Le from Khang Khay [55].
State Department responded to Kong Le defeat by stepping up supply [55].
November, JFK is assassinated. LBJ became President. Over 16,000 US military personnel remained in Laos.
South Vietnamese Premier Diem was assassinated [55].
North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao occupied PDJ [55].

Vang Pao was promoted to General in the Royal Lao Army. 30,000 Hmongs were involved at this time with the fight against the NVA--each being paid 10 cents per day along with the 'promise' of being taken care by the US government [56].
Shong Lue Yang fled back to Tham Ha from Fi Kha after communist attack [49].
NVA, Kong Le and Pathet took Padong stronghold. Hmongs surviving the defeat moved to Yat Mo and then Pha Khao [55].
Gulf of Tonkin incident where North Vietnanmese shoot US destroyer, Maddox, led to retaliation by President Johnson to issue airstrikes against the North Vietnamese [55].
Gulf of Tonkin Resolution is passed and gave Johnson unlimited power to handle Southeast Asia [55].
Shong Lue Yang moved to Kiaw Boua [49].
October, China exploded its first atomic bomb. Krushchev is ousted and replaced by Brezhnev and Kosygin [55].
December, President Johnson is reelected. Operation Barrel Roll is launched as fighter jets in Thailand fly to bomb nothern Lao in support of the Hmongs [55].
Mao Zedong began the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution [55].
Air Force at Udorn Air Base in Thailand was activated to provide air support in secret fights [55].
Operation Rolling Thunder launched to bomb North Vietnam [55].
Shong Lue Yang introduced Second Stage Reduced Version of Pahawh Hmong and Pahawh Khmu [49].
Hmong New Year, Vang Pao took a Laotion wife, Mae La, to prove his love for the Laotions and Laos. [55]
Shong Lue Yang is detained at Long Cheng [49].

Vang Pao's third military base, Na Khang, is taken by NVA and Pathet Lao troops. Prior to the defeat, Vang Pao was shot in the arm by enemy fire and medevacked to Thailand for surgery. By this time, Vang Pao became the undisputed Hmong leader in Indochina, overshadowing Lyfoung Touby. With Vang Pao disabled in Thailand, a coup against him occurred via the efforts of Ly clan members in Long Chieng. Lyfoung Touby was accused of scheming the coup, however, his daughters insist an official investigation ensue to clear their father of this charge [55].
Vang Pao's military success showed as he pushed NVA troops beyond Nam Bac, an area 45 miles from the North Vietnamese border [55].

Vang Pao is a general by this time. Ly Lue and Vang Toua earned their wings as Chaophakaow. Vang Toua is killed in action shortly after taking to the skies. Hmong irregular forces are known as Special Guerrilla Units (SGUs) and later as Groupes Mobiles (GM). By this time, figures estimate that the 20,000 indigenous troops were paid $0.10 per day per person ($2,000 total per day) or $60,000 per month. Auto Defense de Choc (ADC) and Auto Defense Ordinaire (ADO) forces, organized and funded by the Royal Lao government, received weapons and salaries of $2-3 per month or 1,000-2,000 kips per month. During time, the US Department of Defense stepped up involvement with military personnel and supply into Laos. The State Department's counterinsurgency efforts and authority began to diminish [55].
US installed top-secret equipment atop Phou Pha Thi in Laos for 24-7, all-weather precision bombing against targets in north Loas and North Vietnam [55].
Laung Prabang airfield is destroyed by the communist troop [55].
Shong Lue Yang is jailed for contact with followers of Chao Fa in communist-controlled area [49, 55].
50,000 protestors demonstrated against the Vietnam War and LBJ at the Pentagon [55].
November, Bertrand Russell and his International War Crimes Tribunal opened their second session [55].
North Koreans captured USS Pueblo [55].

Hanoi agreed to talk with the US if all bombings stopped. Bombing had stopped as previously agreed on both side due to the Tet New Year. Delay of bombing was to buy Hanoi time to move weapons and troops into position to take over US Air Force base in Phou Pha Thi [55].
General Giap launched Tet Offensive throughout South Vietnam [55].
Hmongs obtained detail NVA plans to take Phou Pha Thi [55].
Phou Pha Thi was attacked by NVA and taken later. American and Hmong versions of the fall of Phou Pha Thi differed [55].
General Vang Pao secretly visited Johnson White House officials, including Special Assistant to the President, Walt Rostow [55].
LBJ ordered a complete halt to all air, naval and artillery bombardment of North Vietnam [55].
Nixon was elected President [55].
LBJ wrote thank you letter to General Vang Pao and for the Hmong handcrafted rifle [55].
December, Captain Fred Walker left Laos assignment for Thailand assignment. General Vang Pao gave Walker a 4 pound silver necklace [55].
Senator William Fulbright revealed that the CIA ran military operations in Laos [55].
Vang Pao proclaimed that Hmongs have earned the right to be called Hmongs and no longer Meo [55].
In Paris, US and North Vietnam agreed on the shape of the negotiating table to be round. Henry A. Kissinger took the place of Averall Harriman under the Nixon Administration [55].
March, In operation Menu, Nixon covertly approved the bombing of Cambodia. Cambodia is believed to be a place of sanctuaries for the NVA [55].
Na Khang, the Alamo, fell. Long Chieng and Bouam Loung (held by Moua Cher Pao) remained among the few remaining centers of importance [55].
Countering the loss of Na Khang, General Vang Pao coordinated US Air supported fight against the NVA at PDJ [55].
May, Nixon proposed NVA and US personnel out of South Vietnam [55].

Nixon annouced unilateral withdrawal of 25,000 troops from South Vietnam. Months later, a 35,000 troop withdrawal followed. These actions were the beggning of the de-Americanization or Vietnamization of Southeast Asia [55].
NVA captured Muong Soui, a strategic military site and airfield for the Royal Lao troops [55].
General Vang Pao ordered air-supported fight to retake Muong Soui. Ly Lue was shot down and killed. [55]
August, General Vang Pao launched Operation About Face to retake PDJ [55].
General Vang Pao succeeded in taking Xieng Khouang and Lima Lima airfield [55].
Ho Chi Minh died [55].
Muong Soui was taken by General Vang Pao troops [55].
October, Senator Stuart Symington conducted secret hearing in Laos [55].

Senator Stuart Symington opened secret hearings on Laos. Under questioning of Symington, Senator JW Fulbright and Roland A. Paul maintained that the US had no moral commitment to Laos, the Lao Royal government or Vang Pao. US efforts in Laos were a commitment to USSR in the Kennedy-Khrushchev agreement of keeping Laos a neutral country [55].
Prince Sihanouk of Cambodia is overthrowned by General Lon Nol [55].
In the early 1970's, the Whitelock Lao-based Alphabet writing system for the Hmong language was created [49].
n the early 1970's, so-called Anonymous Writing System for the Hmong language was created [49].
Ambassador Godley to Laos requested B-52 strikes [55].
February, B-52 began to be used in Laos. Kissinger conducted secret talks with North Vietnamese in Paris [55].
Souvanna Phouma formally requested B-52 strikes [55].
NVA and Pathet Lao drove their way to PDJ. Kissinger recommended Nixon to use B-52 if NVA and Pathet Lao advance beyond Muong Soui [55].
3 B-52's strike NVA and Pathet Lao troops in northern Laos and PDJ area as ordered by Nixon [55].
General Vang Pao ordered Lima Lima and PDJ to be abandoned temporarily. Henry Kissinger prepared for another secret meeting with the Le Duc Tho of North Vietnamese in Paris [55].
Senators Mathias, Mansfield, Gore, Symington, Cooper and Percy attacked Kissinger and Nixon secret policies in Laos [55].
Nixon and Kissinger prepared White House statement on US activities in Laos [55].
Nixon revealed for the first time, US presence in Laos [55].
Round two of Kissinger-Le Duc Tho meeting began [55].
A National Assembly vote removed Prince Norodom Sihanouk as head of state, and General Lon Nol replaced the prince [55].
Thai troops helped Hmongs to defend Long Chieng [55].
NVA troops withdrew from Long Chieng's Skyline [55].
Third Kissinger-Le Duc Tho meeting. The US was blamed for the agression and war [55].
Nixon explained how Vietnamization will be required to eliminate communist sanctuaries in Cambodia [55].
May, Fighther pilot, Vang Seng was shot down in air mission [55].
Ohio National Guardsmen killed four youths in an antiwar demonstration [55].
75,000 to 100,000 war protesters demonstrated in front of the White House [55].
Shong Lue Yang finished Third Stage Reduced Version of Pahawh Hmong [49].
September, McGovern-Hatfield amendment, which set December 31,1971 as the date to withdraw US troops completely, is defeated [55].
Shong Lue Yang is rescued from prison and tkane to Nam Chia [49].
Mission ordered by White House to retrieve US POWs [55].

Fall, Hmong demoralization of heavy losses and disillusionment of US withdrawal suggested the near collapse of the Hmong. It is estimated most Hmong families were reduced to a surviving male of 13 years [55].
Shong Lue Yang finished Pahawh Hmong Final Version.
February, Nixon met Mao Zedong of China [55].

February, Pathet Lao held secret meeting at Vien Sai in the Sam Neua Province, and US resignaled their bold commitment to withdrawal. In this meeting, a central governing body of 7 politburo men were installed. The Lao People's Party became the Lao People's Revolutionary Party, and communist strategy for ultimate takeover of Laos began. Lao leaders included Prince Souphanouvong and the strongest leadership, Kaysone Phomvihane [55].
Operation Lam Son 719 led South Vietnam to cross into Laos and fight North Vietnam [55].
Valentine's Day Massacre occurred when NVA and Pathet Lao attacked Long Chieng [55].
Shong Lue Yang is assasinated [49].
March, Operation Lam Son 719 began to fail as South Vietnamese moved out of Laos [55].
General Vang Pao's troop took enemy positions at Skyline and Phou Pha Xai mountain.

NVA troops launched attack on Bouam Loung, site where Moua Cher Pao swore with his troops in a "drinking of the water" ceremony would never abandon this site. Moua Cher Pao's site is helped by new FAG technology called "offset beacon bombing," where aircraft could lock onto target without visual contact. By the end of May, NVA troops ceased significant efforts to attempt to overtake Bouam Loung [55].
June, Senate passed Mansfield amendment, which called for the President to widthdraw all forces from Southeast Asia provided that American POWs are released by North Vietnam [55].
Mansfield amendment was passed, which stated for the President to withdraw all US troops if Hanoi released US POWs [55].

Le Duc Tho and Kissinger met secretly in Paris. Le Duc Tho agreed to release all US POWs on the day of US withdrawal and with the US to dismantled the South Vietnam Thieu government. Le Duc Tho also demanded war reparations and suggested an assassination of Thieu [55].
July, Kissinger met with Chou En Lai and Mao Zedong as a primer for 1972 Nixon-Zedong meeting. [55]

July, Jane Fonda arrived to act in the theatre of anti-war propaganda. Her presence with NVA anit-aircraft gunners and plea for humane treatment of US POWs were coordinated earlier by North Vietnam in Paris [55].

July, Beginning in July, significant US troops and supply withdrawal would be realized. King Savang Vatthana and Prime Minister Souvanna Phouma ordered General Vang Pao to gain as much territory as possible before the July 1 deadline. General Vang Pao ordered phase 2 of his attempt to remove NVA from PDJ [55].
US and USSR submitted text on banning biological and toxic weapons at the Conference of the Committee on Disarmament [55].
White House make clear they are running the show in Laos and not the CIA or State Department. All plans of operations were required to be submitted 10 days in advance of the operation [55].
Two Russian MIGs are spotted over Ban Ban. Bouam Loung was later bombed [55].
December, North Vietnam launched a massive attack against the Hmong base in northern Laos [55].
NVA launched full scale attack against firebase Tom Tom. Firebase Mustang and Hmong positions, Fox Bravo and Fox Echo, began to fall [55].
Tom Tom and Mustang were overran [55].
Long Chieng was on the eve of destruction by NVA. Ban Sornwas designated the new frontline resupply and redeployment center as Long Chieng fell [55].

Nixon disclosed Kissinger's secret meeting with North Vietnam and commitment to total US withdrawal. He also accepted South Vietnam's President and Vice-President's resignations. The Viet Cong's politcal party, the National Liberation Front, are allowed to participate in South Vietnam's soon presidential elections. Nixon spoke also of spending billions of dollars in Indochina, which North Vietnam may reap, after the post-war years for reconstruction [55].
North Vietnam rejected Nixon's proposals [55].
Nixon signed Biological and Toxin Convention to ban such weapons, although no inspection apparatus is discussed. This treaty was one of many negotiating products of Kissinger-Russian meetings [55].
Kissinger arrived in Moscow secretly. His meeting with Premier Leonid Brezhnev ensured US withdrawal with virtually no need for NVA withdrawal from Laos or South Vietnam [55].
Le Duc Tho-Kissinger meeting in Paris, again, ensured US back out of Southeast Asia [55].

Nixon gained the Republican Presidential Candidate again. He later announced in July of the following year that there would be no more drafting. US troops numbered 47,000 by this time in South Vietnam. [55]
Le Duc Tho-Kissinger meeting in Paris strictly allowed only North Vietnam-US decisions in the removal of US troops and post-US involvement government set up in Southeast Asia [55].
Pathet Lao delegation headed to Vientiane to discuss the ending of the war in Laos. Cease-fire is set for January 23, 1973 [55].
Hanoi approved the 10/8 Le Duc Tho-Kissinger accord [55].
Nixon defeated McGovern for President [55].
Nixon assured South Vietnam President Thieu retaliation if North Vietnam violated the accords. President Thieu instigated changes to Hanoi-Washington accord [55].
Le Duc Tho canceled the accord due to Thieu changes. Nixons issued the "talk or else" policy to Le Duc Tho [55].
Linebacker Two goes on for 11 days bombing Hanoi and strategic sites as part of Nixon's "or else" plan [55].
Hanoi agreed to talk if bombings stopped [55].
Linebacker Two stopped. 26 US aircraft shot down with 93 airmen, while 31 became captured. [55]

Cease-fire under the Agreement on Ending the War and Restoring Peace in Vietnam was signed in Paris. Much was asked of South Vietnam and little of North Vietnam. US troops would completely withdraw in 60 days, while Hanoi's 160,000 troop in South Vietnam and 70,000 troops in Laos remained still [55].
US POWs started to be released by North Vietnam. Their version of POW encampment differed from Jane Fonda. Fonda called the POWs hypocrites and liars [55].
General Vang Pao married May Song Moua, a nurse, as his third wife [55].

Peace agreement by the Lao called the Agreement on the Restoration of Peace and Reconciliation in Laos was signed. Royal capital Laung Prabang and administrative capital Vientiane were neutralized by having communists troops there as co-protectors. Cease-fire was effective 2/23 [55].
April, Pathet Lao revised the Agreement as a strategic blueprint for more gains [55].
The Vientiane Agreement was signed and signaled the collapse of the Royal Lao power [55].
November, Congress passed the War Powers Act, rendering presidential retaliation for violation of peace treaties impossible [55].
40,000 North Vietnamese troops remain in Laos [55].

January, National Geographic article by W.E. Garrett's article appeared documenting Dr. Yang Dao and LyTeck Ly Nhia Vue's optimistic views for the new coalition government of Laos. LyTeck Ly Nhia Vue professed the Pathet Lao will appoint him over Yang Dao as Hmong leader to replace Vang Pao [55].
June, The last Air America plane and US military personnel left Laos [55].
August, a student-lead political protest stormed in Vientiane to promote their 18 point program, which called for eliminating all foreign sources of cultural vices [55].
August, Nixon is replaced by Ford as President due to Watergate Scandal [55].
August, Borders of Laos is closed. Mekong River became an Iron Curtain, and isolated the Laotian government as a gulag [55].
Souvanna Phouma returned from France for medical treatment of a heart attack [55].
Souvanna Phouma was recorded telling American professor Joesph Zasloff that Laos would not go communist [55].
LyFong Touby met with General Vang Pao and investigated his options to defect. LyFong returned to Laos and was sent to Seminar Camp 5, where in 1979 he died [55].
General Vang Pao was evacuated to Thailand [55].
General Vang Pao was living in Montana [55].
January, North Vietnam launched offensive against South Vietnam. Congress denied Ford's request for aid to South Vietnam [55].
January, US ratified Biological and Toxin Convention [55].
The Lao People's Revolutionary Army (LPRA) and NVA attacked the Royal Lao at Sala Phou Khoun. [55]
USSR ratified Biological and Toxin Convention [55].
General Vang Pao troops protecting Sala Phou Khoun were under attack by LPRA troops [55].

Again, General Vang Pao troops protecting Sala Phou Khoun are under attack by LPRA troops. Prime Minister Souvanna Phouma criticized General Vang Pao for protecting Sala Phou Khoun. Dr. Yang Dao toured communist countries seeking support for a Laos coalition government. General Vang Pao under criticism planned to take Lao Air Force [55].
China-backed Pol Pot's communist Khmer Rouge took Cambodia [55].
Last US evacuation helicopter lifted off from the US Embassy in Saigon as the city is taken by the NVA. Saigon became Ho Chi Minh City and news of US-South Vietnam defeat reached Laos [55].

General Vang Pao at Long Chieng conducted a meeting among Hmong leaders regarding the decision to fight. They analyze the Paris Agreement of 1973 (Le Duc Tho-Kissinger), Agreement on the Restoration of Peace and Reconciliation of Laos, Vientiane Agreement, 18 point policy and a May 6th radio broadcast equivocally threatening the Hmong and other strategic military topics. By this time, Dr. Yang Dao is promoting Hmong integration with the LPRA government and was back from his communist country tour [55].
NVA took Sala Phou Khoun. Discussion of evacuation turned imminent among the Hmong and General Vang Pao. [55]

General Vang Pao was issued an ultimatum by the CIA to evacuate. General Vang Pao and 12 Hmongs signed a treaty acknowledging previous American pledges and their own pledge to never return to Laos. Prime Minister Souvanna Phouma replaced General Vang Pao on this day as Commander of Military Region II [55].
Hmong exodus from Laos began on C-47 planes. Dr. Yang Dao arrived at Long Chieng and fled as well.
Prince Sisouk na Champassak sent the last artillery support of Long Chieng before fleeing Laos.

General Vang Pao left Long Chieng to Phou Khang to bid farewell to Hmong villagers. He stopped at Muang Cha to board a plane to his final destination (Nam Phong) at Udorn Air Base. Some Hmongs, who no more planes would come for, but determined to follow General Vang Pao, set out on foot westward towards Ban Sorn. At Ban Sorn, some Hmongs determined going to Vientiane would be a much better option.
General Vang Pao's replacement arrived, named, General Chao Manivong with LyFong Touby at Long Chieng .

Souvanna Phouma ordered LyFong Touby to persauve Hmongs to stop exodus into Thailand. Touby made a speech at Ban Sorn to thousands of Hmong that they have no worry since they are the population, and the problem, referring to General Vang Pao and those who had gone to Thailand, were gone. His speech was closely monitored by Pathet Lao officials [55].
10,000 Hmongs in exodus at Hin Heup Bridge were opened fire upon by the Pathet Lao [55].
June, US Air Foce was deactivated in Thailand [55].

Radio Pathet Lao reported its version of Hin Heup Bridge Massacre, citing Hmong attacks and disruption. Sia Sivang was noted in this broadcast as General Vang Pao's henchman. Prince Sai Kham, the last prince of Xieng Khouang, crossed the Mekong River and took refuge in a Thai Buddha temple [55].
Radio Pathet Lao announced Royal Lao Army officers request of Pathet Lao advisors. More propaganda against Hmong exodus was broadcast [55].
Vientiane Domestic Service airs Order 904 which required all weapons to be returned to arsenal depots in their respective military regions [55].
July, Former senior Royal Lao civilians and military were rounded up for seminar camps [55].
Royal Lao-Pathet Lao coalition government stopped. Pathet Lao controlled Laos as USSR supply move in and a house-cleaning of the old governing officials begins [55].
Lao-Thai border closed [55].
September, the people of the traditional governing structure in Laos are eliminated [55].
Vientiane rallied for abdication of the king occurred [55].
December, As the Lao People's Revolutionary Party took over, monarchy was abolished. Lao became known as LPDR [55].

By the time US troops evacuated Southeast Asia, 17,000 Hmong soldiers and 5,000 Hmong civilians were killed. An additional 100,000 Hmongs died in their flight from the communist Laos and Vietnam government to the US-backed Thailand refugee camps. In all, 122,000 Hmong lives were taken during and immediately after the Secret War [55].

The Kingdom of Laos was now the Lao People's Democratic Republic (LPDR). The Program of Action by the LPDR was enacted as well, and Kaysone Phomvihane replaced Prince Souphanouvong as the new leader. The royalty of Laos is effectively discontinued [55].
LyTeck Ly Nhia Vue was executed at Seminar Camp 6 [55].
LPDR and People's Army of Vietnam (PAVN) began the use of chemical-biological toxin warfare against Hmongs in Laos.
Carter was elected President [55].
Ban Vinai camp is created [55].
Lao royal family (King Savang Vatthana, Queen Khamphoui and Prince Vongsavang) was arrested and imprisoned in Seminar Camp 1, Sop Hoa at Vieng Sai, where LyFong Touby was also encamped [55].
Carter's 1977 Country Reports on Human Rights Practices (426 pages) did not list the country of Laos. [55]
March, Carter explored the recognition of a communist Vietnam [55].

The Treaty of Friendship and Cooperation between LPDR and Socialist Republic of Vietnam reaffirmed the commitment to Marxims-Leninism and provided the legal basis for Vietnam involvement in Laos [55].

Communists massacred Hmong in Phou Bia area and started the "final solution" to exterminate Hmongs. Pathet Lao defectors estimate 50,000 were dead of poison and 45,000 were shot, died of starvation or tortured to death at Phou Bia [55].
Lyfoung Touby died at re-education camp in Sam Neua [55].
Pa Kao Her formed Ethnics Liberation Organization of Laos [49].
Prince Vongsavang died at Seminar Camp 1 [55].
June, Vietnam joined Comecon, the East European economic community. Carter signed SALT II with Premier Brezhnev [55].
King Savang Vatthana died at Seminar Camp 1 [55].
Queen Khamphoui died after she is moved to Seminar Camp 2 at Houei Bao in Houa Phan [55].
Soviet invaded Afghanistan in December [55].
December, Vietnam invaded Chinese-backed Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge and installed pro-Hanoi government in Cambodia [55].

Fall, Gary B. Croker of the State Department's Bureau of Intelligence and Research began investigation of biological/toxic chemical use in Laos with Colonel Charles W. Lewis as head of the investigation team [55].
Prince Sisouk na Champassak accused the world of a "conspiracy of silence" on the atrocities in Laos [55].
February, China invaded Vietnam [55].
April, Explosion of Soviet secret military compound released toxins and caused death [55].
Iran took American hostages [55].
Reagan was elected President [55].
December, UN adopted a resolution to investigate the use of chemical-biological warfare in Laos, Cambodia and Afghanistan [55].
Supporters of Pahawh Hmong formed Motthem Family [49].
Western scientists detected chemical agent used against Hmong, Cambodians and Afghanistanians. The origins of the chemicals used against the Hmongs were determined to be from the Soviet Union [55].

Lao and Hmong leaders, prompted by Prince Sisouk na Champassak and General Vang Pao, formed the United Lao National Liberation Front (ULNLF). Their goals were to break the conspiracy of silence and call for world support against the Kaysone government. ULNLF is also known as Neo Hom [55].

At the request of several Hmong leaders, General Vang Pao wrote to the Secretary of State Haig to complain of the Department of State's accusation of Hmong as heroin traffickers. General Vang Pao asked for an investigation into the use of bio-toxic chemicals against the Hmongs [55].

The Secretary of State's assistance's (John Holdridge) response to General Vang Pao reiterated that the UN had voted for an investigation and Congress has held hearings on the use of bio-toxin chemicals in Laos. [55]
Dr. Yang Dao presented a paper at the University of Minnesota in an attempt to exonerate himself from negative communist associations [55].

Senator Hayakawa of California arrived in Laos. His visit is reported in March 1982, and although he is informed prior to his visit of bio-toxin chemical warfare against the Hmongs, Sen. Hayakawa's report does not mention anything regarding this issue [55].

Secretary of State Alexander Haig revealed US physical evidence of bio-toxic chemicals used in Southeast Asia to the Berlin Press Association. His announcements suggested the producers of such chemicals were from the USSR. Haig's statements were based on the National Intelligence Estimates [55].
US Senate Subcommittee on Arms Control scheduled hearing on biological weapons use in Southeast Asia and Afghanistan [55].

Dr. Khamseng Keo Sengsathit, Director of Public Health for LPDR, defected to China. He denounced the Le Duan (Vietnamese government) for the occupation of Laos, their expansionist policies and their use of chemical-biological weapons against national minorities [55].
Spring, LAWASIA launched investigation into CBW and concluded that CBW technology were employed in Southeast Asia [55].
House of Rep held hearings on chemical-biological weapons use in Laos, Cambodia and Afghanistans. [55]

Secretary of State Alexander Haig submitted Chemical Warfare in Southeast Asia and Afghanistan based on National Intelligence Estimates. The report cited USSR and Vietnam use of CBW in Afghanistan and Southeast Asia, respectively [55].
Jerry Daniels, a long-time friend of the Hmong and veteran of the Indochina atrocious saga, died [55].
Ntawv Puaj Txwm, or the Syaboury Alphabet, is shown to United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees field officer, Nina Wimuttikosol, by Nkaj Vas Hawj [49].

Jack Anderson and Dale Van Atta offered explanation regarding US disinterest in bio-toxic chemical use in Laos. They noted that CIA analyst and biological weapons (BW) expert Julian Hoptman, the dominating figure in BW, simply gave no credence to any report hinting the cheating of the Soviets due to his commitment to the 1972 Biological and Toxin Weapons Convention [55].
Phang Day Lo died [55].
Reagan was reelected President [55].
Nova's The Mystery of Yellow Rain was aired. A pro-Meselson bee-dung theory view was presented [55].
Thailand began to repatriate Hmong refugees to Laos [55].
Txoov Yias Yaj was invited by the Institute for Southeast Asian Studies in Kunming, Yunnan to teach RPA to the Hmong Chinese [49].

June, Her Pa Kao, the leader of Chao Fa, appeared in Angola in a meeting with Angola's Jonas Savimbi, Nicaraguan Democratic Force representatives and Afghan mujahedeen. This meeting was sponsored by millionaire Lewis Lehrman, founder of Citizens for America. Pa Kao Her left the meeting coronated as head of the Lao freedom fighters. This coronation teared apart and confused the Hmong community internationally regarding who was the ultimate Hmong leader [55].
August, Pa Kao Her appeared in Texas sponsored by the US Council for World Freedom, chaired by retired Army Major General John K Singlauv [55].
Pa Kao Her's 6 hours meeting in St. Paul, MN with Hmong leaders was taped. Yang Dao was present at this meeting as well [55].
"A Journey to Laos," is produced by American Friends Service Committee workers, Jacqui Chagnon and Roger Rumpf [55].
Thailand's National Security Chief reports LPDR was involved in heroin trafficking [55].
LPDR narcotics-related corruption caused Laos not to receive US assistance [55].
Bush was President [55].
UN and US chartered the Comprehensive Plan of Action [55].

Lawyers Committee for Human Rights issued reports warning that the procedure for determining refugee status was conducted haphazardly, that extortion and bribery were widespread and that the "Office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in Thailand has proven incapable of ensuring a reliable and fair procedure. [55]
Kaysone Phomvihane commended China for the crackdown on student demonstrations at Tiananmen Square. [55]
LPDR make clear linkage between cooperation with US on POW/MIAs and on narcotics issues [55].
November, The Berlin Wall crumbled, and so does the rest of European communist governments [55].

December, ULNLF announced creation of Provisional Democratic Government inside Laos with 10,000 troops. They elected Prince Suriyavong Vongsavang to be king. Prince Phayaluang Outhong would be prime minister and General Vang Pao would be first deputy prime minister. Kaysone was enraged and vowed to bomb Laos until the Free Lao forces were exterminated [55].
LPDR remained a major opium trafficking state [55].
Glasnost and perestroika movement dominated Eastern Europe's communist policy [55].
Soviet support for LPDR diminished [55].
Census report in China estimated 7,398,035 Miao in China [2]. 3,686,900 in Guizhou 1,557,073 in Hunan 896,712 in Yunnan 535,923 in Sichuan 425,137 in Guanxi 200,702 in Hubei 52,044 in Nanhai
20 MiG-21s from Vietnam dropped explosive and CBW in resistance area [55].
Resistance forces weakened significantly as PAVN and LPDR air forces bombed strategic areas. [55]
US-funded construction programs began in Laos as part of a $8.7 million several-year aid package. [55]
LPDR pubished a draft of its constitution in Pasason newspaper [55].
July, Lao resistance radio began to be broadcasted.
Radio Station of the Government of Liberation and of the Lao Nation called for the abolition of Marxist-Lenin style of government [55].
October, LPDR jailed communist cabinet vice-ministers for promoting a multi-party system [55].
6 LPDR officers denouncing Lao government were jailed. Phoumi Vongvichit was now acting President of LPDR [55].
"Laos: Human Rights in a Forgotten Country," took place at Yale [55].

Vue Mai was used to promote repatriation within the refugee camps. He was also backed by the US to travel to the US to quell fears and concerns among journalists, legislators, human rights advocates and Hmongs living in the US [55].
Americans appealed to Congress without success or response for 3 years [55].
Laos began to lobby Congress for Most Favored Nation (MFN) trade status [55].
Vang Wangyee organized the Lao Veteran of America [55].
Soviet Union collapsed and its aid to Laos ended [55].
March, Fifth Lao Party Congress in Vientiane reaffirmed commitment to Marxism-Leninism [55].

Vue Mai's 10 point proposal kicked off self-volunteer repatriation of refugees from Thailand to Laos. 2 months later, this document was released in the US. Vue Mai was aided by US Rober Robinson and Briton Rober Cooper in drafting this document [55].
Bush administration gave Laos helicopter and training as US anti-narcotics aid [55].
June, US,UN,Laos and Thailand began repatriation programs of Hmongs from Thailand refugee camps back to Laos by way of the Tripartite Agreement [55].
August, Laos' Constitution was ratified, a Bill of Rights was absent [55].
Vue Mai is asked by the US State Department to lead the Hmong back to Laos under the monitoring and auspices of the UNHCR [55].
LPDR remained the 3rd largest producer of opium, producing 230 tons of opium or 19 tons of heroin [55].
November, Kaysone died [55].
Clinton was President. State Department denied Hmong repatriation atrocities [55].
15,000 Hmongs in Thailand refugee camps escaped repatriation to Laos and seeked asylum in Buddhist temples [55].
Vue Mai disappeared in Vientiane, Laos and was never heard from again [55].

Thirty years after Hmong and Americans came together in Laos, former CIA director, William E. Colby, testified to Congress the efforts of General Vang Pao against General Vo Nguyen Giap's 70,000 troops [55].
The House Foreign Affairs Committee added momentum to hold hearing on Laos's MFN application [55].
Fall 1994, a bipartisan effort informed Secretary of State Warren Christopher about the efficacy of the Tripartite Agreement [55].

February 1994, Marc Kaufman writes in the Philadelphia Inquirer about the ongoing involuntary repatriation of Hmongs to Laos and described a campaign by personnel of the US State Department and UNHCR to discredit Hmong American Leaders and Hmong refugees [55].
The House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs scheduled this date for hearings.
October 1994, Brian Bonner documented abuses against Hmongs by LPDR [55].
November 1994, Rep. Benjamin Gilman (NY) became the Chair of House Committees for International Relations [55].

Refugee camps for the Hmongs in Thailand were all closed. Forced repatriation of Hmong refugee to Laos began while Thai, US and UN all approved this deadly measure despite facts and evidence revealing the political and human-rights state of Laos [56].

January 1995, Rep. Steve Gunderson (WI), Gilman and Rep. Christopher Smith (NJ), the new chair of the Subcommittee on International Operations and Human Rights, began a five-man fact-finding mission to Thailand. [55]

March 1995, Reports from Gunderson's-Gilman-Smith efforts found truth about State Department's deception and coverup of forced Hmong-repatritation atrocities. UNHCR was also found to have been feeding misleading information to Congress regarding Hmong repatriation [55].
Repatriation of Hmong is stopped [55].
A tradition is started as an annual May 14 and May 15th DC event honors Hmong and Lao Vietnam Veterans [55].
3,000 veterans of General Vang Pao's army were recognized for their efforts in the secret war. Vietnam Veterans National Medals were awarded [55].
Fresno City College dedicated a permanent memorial to Hmong Veterans on Memorial day [55].
July. The Chinese government erected a temple in honor of ZhiYou, Huangdi and Yandi in Zhuolu [1].
Zhang Xiumei, the Hmong leader during the Miao Rebellion was recognized by the Chinese government as a great leader against imperial rule [1].
